author: Lam Van Le
title: Bilateral femoral head avascular necrosis
text:
Presentation
Pain and limited mobility in both hip joints, more severe on the left side.
Patient Data
[Bilateral femoral head avascular necrosis](/cases/bilateral-femoral-head-avascular-necrosis-11?lang=us)
Serpiginous [signal abnormalities](#annotation-37255) are observed in the anterosuperior aspects of both femoral heads, more pronounced on the left. These findings indicate avascular necrosis (AVN), characterized by a serpentine sclerotic rim appearing hypointense on T1W and T2W sequences. [Bone marrow edema](#annotation-37256) is present in the left femoral head. A subchondral fracture is noted at the margin of the left femoral head, with a clear [crescent sign](#annotation-37253) appearance.
Significant[ joint effusion](#annotation-37254) is observed in the left hip joint.
Appear unremarkable, with no significant abnormalities detected.
Case Discussion
The MRI findings are consistent with bilateral [osteonecrosis of the femoral head](/articles/osteonecrosis-of-the-femoral-head?lang=us), classified as stage III on the left and stage II on the right according to the[ ARCO](/articles/arco-classification-of-femoral-head-osteonecrosis?lang=us) 2019 classification.
